SENT.plain: Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) is an inherited pure red blood cell aplasia that often requires lifelong transfusional support
The origin of the imperfect erythrogenesis is not known
The existence of more than one molecular basis for DBA is indicated by its different modes of inheritance and widely variable clinical phenotypes
Several erythroid growth factors have been thought to have a role in the pathogenesis of DBA
However, there is neither molecular nor clinical evidence for the involvement of stem cell factor or interleukin-3

The observation of elevated erythropoietin (EPO) concentrations and an impaired in vivo and in vitro response to pharmacologic doses of recombinant human EPO has suggested a defective EPO function in the pathogenesis of DBA
We have investigated the possible involvement of the EPO receptor (EPO-R) gene in 23 patients by screening its coding sequence for mutations using single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP)
A Southern blot and hybridization with an EPO-R probe was also performed on DNA from seven patients
The absence of concordant segregation of the disease with the EPO-R gene in two informative families ruled out its role in their DBA children
These findings demonstrate that DBA is not commonly associated with EPO-R gene mutations
